channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Trying to Save Russia’s Punch Line of a Car
item.description: Russians ridicule their endangered Ladas, but also cherish them. So the Kremlin recruited a blunt Swedish-American executive with long experience in Detroit to overhaul the carmaker.
item.dc:creator: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Russians ridicule but also cherish their endangered Ladas. So the Kremlin recruited a blunt Swedish-American executive with long experience in Detroit to overhaul their maker.

item.title: Woman Killed While Protesting Chinese Copper Mine in Myanmar
item.description: Villagers said the 56-year-old was shot by security forces as the police and Chinese employees of the mine erected a fence after land had been seized to expand the project.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER and WAI MOE

item.title: Spain’s Princess Cristina to Stand Trial on Tax Fraud Charges
item.description: Cristina de Borbon, sister of Spain’s King Felipe VI and sixth in line to the throne, will be the first Spanish royal to face prosecution.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Ex-Cabinet Minister Wins Tunisian Presidential Runoff
item.description: Beji Caid Essebsi won 55.68 percent of the vote in the country’s first free and democratic balloting for the post, Tunisia’s election commission said.
item.dc:creator: By CARLOTTA GALL

item.title: Robert Mugabe Dismisses More Government Officials in Zimbabwe
item.description: Amid fears of political turmoil gripping southern Africa, a separate political feud in neighboring Zambia was reported to have been resolved.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: A Child With H.I.V., Shunned by His Entire Village
item.description: More than 200 villagers in the southwestern province of Sichuan, including the boy’s guardian, have signed a petition unanimously calling for the boy’s expulsion.
item.dc:creator: By DAN LEVIN

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Restaurant in Beijing Temple Rejects State Media Censure
item.description: Temple Restaurant Beijing, which serves French-influenced cuisine, has countered that it is a properly licensed business that is open to the public and has not engaged in any illegal operations.
item.category: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization
item.dc:creator: By JESS MACY YU
item.media:description: Security guards outside the Songzhu Temple compound in Beijing. The temple is one of two near the Forbidden City that the Xinhua news agency said contained restaurants catering to China's elites.

item.title: Laszlo Varga, Cellist for the New York Philharmonic, Is Dead at 89
item.description: After escaping a Nazi work camp, Mr. Varga became principal cellist for the New York Philharmonic in 1951 and remained in the post for 11 years.
item.dc:creator: By BRUCE WEBER
item.media:description: For a time, Laszlo Varga was a New York Philharmonic fixture.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Beijing Battles Decline in Tourism
item.description: Beijing is considering several measures to increase tourism, including extending visa-free entry to 96 hours, the government-run newspaper China Daily reported.
item.dc:creator: By BREE FENG
item.media:description: A section of the Great Wall of China in Mutianyu, near Beijing. The capital is reportedly considering a number of measures to reverse a decline in international tourism, including extending visa-free entry to 96 hours.

item.title: Cuba Seizures Now Present Opportunities
item.description: Lawyers are scrambling to determine whether normalized relations with Cuba will create a chance to get compensation for lost properties now estimated to be worth nearly $7 billion.
item.dc:creator: By FRANCES ROBLES
item.media:description: Lois and Roy Schechter on their farm in Pinar del Río, Cuba, in 1957. The property was seized by the government in 1960. Mrs. Schechter hopes policy changes will lead to compensation.

item.title: Sports of The Times: In Cuba, Baseball Remains a Grand Preoccupation
item.description: In Cuba, from the baseball games on the fields to those played in streets with balls wrapped in duct tape, it’s a love pursued amid the ruins.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL POWELL
item.media:description: A pickup game in Barrio Cerro, where young men played on a basketball court and shared a single glove.

item.title: Munich Journal: He Sees You When You’re Sleeping, and Gives You Nightmares
item.description: In Germany, misbehaving children had better watch out. The Krampus, a devilish goblin who tears through the streets as St. Nick’s evil counterpart, is making a comeback.
item.dc:creator: By MELISSA EDDY
item.media:credit: Gordon Welters for The New York Times
item.media:description: A member of the “Sparifankerl Pass,” or “Devil’s Group,” elicits delight, and horror, in Munich.

item.title: In 2008 Mumbai Attacks, Piles of Spy Data, but an Uncompleted Puzzle
item.description: An investigation reveals how American, British and Indian agencies failed to pull together intelligence streams, including a plotter’s online activity, before attacks that Indians regard as their 9/11.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES GLANZ, SEBASTIAN ROTELLA and DAVID E. SANGER
item.media:description: Indian police on guard outside the Taj Mahal Palace Hotel on Nov. 28, 2008.

item.title: Christie Wants Obama to Push Cuba to Return New Jersey Trooper’s Killer
item.description: Joanne Chesimard, who goes by the name Assata Shakur, was convicted in the 1973 killing of a New Jersey state trooper and fled to Cuba.
item.dc:creator: By EMMA G. FITZSIMMONS
item.media:description: Joanne Chesimard, convicted of killing Trooper Werner Foerster, escaped from a New Jersey prison.

item.title: Old-Guard Politician Seen Leading Tunisia’s Interim President in Runoff Election
item.description: Exit polls indicated that Beji Caid Essebsi, who served two dictators, was ahead of President Moncef Marzouki, a former human rights activist, who did not concede defeat.
item.dc:creator: By CARLOTTA GALL
item.media:description: A Tunisian voter at a polling station in Tunis on Sunday.

item.title: World Briefing: Pakistan: Four More Militants Hanged
item.description: Pakistan hanged four Islamist militants on Sunday in the second set of executions since the government reinstated the death penalty after a Taliban massacre at a school last week.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Afghanistan: Taliban Attack Police
item.description: The Taliban attacked a checkpoint in northern Afghanistan, killing at least seven police officers, an official said Sunday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: India: Bomb Kills 3 at Bus Station
item.description: An explosion in the parking lot of a bus station on Sunday killed three people and wounded five others in India’s remote northeastern state of Manipur, where several separatist groups operate, the police said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Haiti: Interim Premier Named
item.description: Health Minister Florence Duperval Guillaume was named as Haiti’s interim prime minister on Sunday after the resignation of her predecessor a week ago.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Nigeria: Video Shows a Massacre
item.description: A new video from Boko Haram extremists shows gunmen shooting civilians lying face down in a dormitory and a leader saying they are being killed because they are “infidels.”
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
